case_name: Anil Kumar Bose and Raghunath Prasad v. State

facts.text: Criminal Appeal Nos. 223 and 224 of 1970 are appeals by special leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 4th August 1970 of the Patna High Court in Crl. Appeals Nos. 213 and 236 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal Nos. 223 and 224 of 1970. Appeals by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 4th August 1970 of the Patna High Court in Crl. Appeals Nos. 213 and 236 of 1967.

facts.text: Patna High Court convicted the two appellants and another under section 420/34, Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: against the judgment of the Patna High Court companyvicting the two appellants and another under section 420/34, Indian Penal Code. They have each been sentenced.

facts.text: Each convict sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for one year and a fine of Rs. 200/-, in default rigorous imprisonment for six months.

anchor.surface_text: They have each been sentenced. to rigorous imprisonment for one year and a fine of Rs. 200/-, in default regorous imprisonment for six months.

facts.text: Dr. Rama Shankar PW 14 and Dr. Ram Balak Singh PW 4 were House Physicians and Dr. Sailendra Kumar PW 5 was a House Surgeon in the Darbhanga Medical College Hospital.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Rama Shankar  PW 14  and Dr. Ram Balak Singh  PW 4  were 90 3 House Physicians. and Dr. Sailendra Kumar  PW 5  was a House Surgeon in the Durbhanga Medical College Hospital.

facts.text: House Surgeons or House Physicians appointed for six months periods January to June and July to December with monthly emoluments Rs. 125/- (Rs. 75/- stipend and Rs. 50/- diet allowance).

anchor.surface_text: Hospital House Surgeons or House Physicians are usually appointed for different sections of the Hospital by the Superintendent of the Hospital for a period of six months, January to June and July to December and their monthly emoluments total Rs. 125/- Rs. 75/- towards stipend and Rs. 50, as diet allowance.

facts.text: Fictitious pay bill for Rs. 125/- for March 1963 prepared in name of Dr. Rama Shankar who worked only up to December 1962 and handed over charge in January 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case is that for the month of March 1963 a fictitious pay bill for Rs. 125/ was prepared in the name of Dr. Rama Shankar, who had worked only for six months up to December, 1962 and had made over charge in January 1963.

facts.text: Similar fictitious pay bill for March 1963 prepared for Dr. Sailendra Kumar in Pediatric Section though he worked in Ear, Nose and Throat Department.

anchor.surface_text: A similar pay bill for March 1963 was prepared for Dr. Sailandra Kumar, who was working in Ear, Nose and Throat Department, but this bill was prepared in the Pediatric Section.

facts.text: Fictitious pay bill for March 1963 prepared in name of Dr. Ram Balak Singh who never joined the post and was substituted by Dr. Rana Chandraketu.

anchor.surface_text: Likewise another fictitious pay bill for the same month was prepared in the name of Dr. Ram Balak Singh, although he never joined that post and he was substituted by Dr. Rana Chandraketu.

facts.text: Amounts of the three pay bills drawn from Treasury and disbursed to fictitious persons.

anchor.surface_text: The amounts of the three aforesaid pay bills were drawn from the Treasury and disbursed to fictitious persons.

facts.text: Yogesh Prasad Thakur was the Bill Clerk who prepared the pay bills.

anchor.surface_text: Yogesh Prasad Thakur was the Bill Clerk, who has number appealed against his companyviction. The Accountant, Raghunath Prasad and the Cashier, Anil Kumar Bose, are the two appellants before us.

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 223 of 1970 by Anil Kumar Bose (Cashier) and No. 224 of 1970 by Raghunath Prasad (Accountant).

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 223 of 1970 is by Anil Kumar Bose and Criminal Appeal No. 224 of 1970 is by Raghunath Prasad. Both these appeals are heard together and are disposed of by this companymon judgment.

facts.text: Pay bills prepared by Bill Clerk, checked by Accountant, signed by Superintendent, taken to Treasury by peon, money to Cashier for disbursement per Acquittance Roll, certified by Deputy Superintendent.

anchor.surface_text: According to the rules of procedure, such pay bills used to be prepared by the Bill Clerk, checked by the Accountant and then placed for signature before the Superintendent of the Hospital. After his signature, the bills were handed over to the peon of the Hospital who took these to the Treasury and after companylecting the money therefrom made over the same to the Cashier, who made relevant entries in his cash Book and other companynected registers. Then, in accordance with the Acquittance Roll, the money used to be disbursed to the various persons who signed in token of receipt of the amounts on the Acquittance Roll. After disbursement of the money, a certificate used to be given by the Deputy Suprintendent to the effect that the money had been disbursed in his presence.

facts.text: In May 1963, Head Clerk Bhola Nath Jha PW 3 noticed more Housemen than sanctioned strength in Acquittance Roll for March 1963 during preparation of Annual Establishment Return.

anchor.surface_text: Some time in may 1963, in the companyrse of preparation of the Annual Establishment Return for submission to the Accountant General, Bihar, the Head Clerk, Bhola Nath Jha  PW 3  numbericed that in the Acquittance Roll for March 1963, there were names of more Housemen than the sanctioned strength.

facts.text: After enquiry, police lodged information and submitted charge-sheet against two appellants and Bill Clerk.

anchor.surface_text: After enquiry by several officers at different levels, an information was lodged to the police who ultimately submitted a charge-sheet against the two appellants and Yogesh Prasad Thakur, the Bill Clerk.

facts.text: Sessions Court convicted accused under 420/34 IPC, High Court affirmed conviction and sentence.

anchor.surface_text: The accused were tried by the Court of Sessions ending in their companyviction under section 420/ 34 I.P.C. The High Court or appeal affirmed the companyviction and sentence.

facts.text: Bill Clerk Yogesh Prasad Thakur's conviction accepted by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: We are number companycerned with the companyviction of the Bill Clerk, Yogesh Prasad Thakur, who accepted the same.

facts.text: Accountant Raghunath Prasad's defence: bills did not pass through him, no knowledge, directly to Superintendent.

anchor.surface_text: The defence of the Accountant, Raghunath Prasad, is that these bills did number pass through him and so he had numberknowledge about the companyrectness of the same and they were directly put up before the Superintendent of the Hospital for his signature and he signed them.

facts.text: Cashier Anil Kumar Bose's defence: no role in preparation, disbursed per Acquittance Roll, did not know the three Doctors personally.

anchor.surface_text: The defence of the Cashier, Anil Kumar Bose, is that he has numberhing to do with the preparation of the bills. He came into the picture when the entire cash of these bills and other bills was handed over to him and he disbursed the money in accordance with the Acquittance Roll, as prepared by the Accounts Department. He did number know these three Doctors personally and he was number guilty of cheating.

facts.text: Supreme Court acquitted the two appellants, set aside High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeals ,are allowed. The judgment of the High Court so far as these two appellants are companycerned is set aside. The two appellants herein are acquitted of the charge and shall be discharged from their bail bonds.

facts.text: Disputed pay bills do not bear initial or signature of the Accountant below Superintendent's signature.

anchor.surface_text: it is further interesting to numbere thatthe disputed pay bills do number bear the initial or signature ofthe Accountant below the signature of the Superintendent

facts.text: Payment to PW5 made on 5th April and next on 10th April for same name.

anchor.surface_text: In case of P.W. 5 one payment was made on the 5th April for the month of March and the next payment to a person of that name was made on 10th April, that is, only after five days.

facts.text: No signature of Deputy Superintendent obtained on disputed entries in Acquittance Roll.

anchor.surface_text: In these disputed cases numbersuch signature was obtained of the Deputy Superintendent, and .there is numberexplanation as to why this was number done.

arguments.claim: Accountant's failure to check bills is at highest administrative lapse, not guilty intention for 420 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: On the above evidence at the highest it was a failure on the part of the Accountant to perform his duties or to observe the rules of procedure laid down in the Duty Chart in a proper manner and may, there-fore, be an administrative lapse on his part about which we are number required to pronounce any opinion in this case.

arguments.claim: High Court incorrect to hold Accountant purposely avoided signing to absolve responsibility; Superintendent's evidence contrary.

arguments.claim: Evidence insufficient to establish mens rea against Cashier; at highest error of judgment or breach of duty, not dishonest intention.

anchor.surface_text: On the evidence which the High Court has relied upon against him, it is number possible to hold that the requisite mens rea has been established against this accused. As observed in the case of the Accountant, it may be at the highest a case of an error of judgment or breach of performance of duty which, per se, cannot be equated with dishonest intention

arguments.claim: Superintendent and Deputy Superintendent showed carelessness allowing latitude to employees.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the Superintendent and the Deputy Superintendent have shown carelessness in their duties and these things came to happen because of the latitude whic

arguments.court_reasoning: Supports giving benefit of doubt to appellants.

holdings.text: Failure on the part of the Accountant to perform his duties or observe rules of procedure is at highest an administrative lapse, not guilty intention essential for offence of cheating under section 420 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: On the above evidence at the highest it was a failure on the part of the Accountant to perform his duties or to observe the rules of procedure laid down in the Duty Chart in a proper manner and may, there-fore, be an administrative lapse on his part about which we are number required to pronounce any opinion in this case. Without, however, anything more we do number think it will be companyrect to impute to this appellant a guilty intention which is one of the essential ingredients of the offence of cheating under section 420 I.P.C.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows lack of initials on bills and procedural deviation by Superintendent; no further evidence of knowledge or dishonest intent; imputation of mens rea requires more than lapse.

holdings.text: High Court lacked material to hold Accountant purposely avoided signing bills to absolve responsibility.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from this, the High Court is number companyrect and indeed had numbermaterial to hold that the Accountant did number purposely sign on these forged bills with a view to get himself absolved of the responsibility. The evidence of the Superintendent, which is extracted above, runs companynter to that companyclusion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Superintendent's evidence contradicts High Court's inference; no purposeful act proven.

holdings.text: Duty Chart does not require Cashier to verify payee identity; no evidence Cashier knew the doctors or detected fraud; benefit of reasonable doubt applies.

anchor.surface_text: Even on the finding of the High Court, there was numberhing in the Duty Chart that the duty of the Cashier was to see that the payment was made to the companyrect or right person. There is further numberevidence that these three Doctors were known to the Cashier.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court conceded Cashier may not know all Housemen; absence of explicit duty and knowledge; carelessness by superiors noted.

holdings.text: Requisite mens rea not established against Cashier; error of judgment or breach of duty not equivalent to dishonest intention for section 420 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: On the evidence which the High Court has relied upon against him, it is number possible to hold that the requisite mens rea has been established against this accused. As observed in the case of the Accountant, it may be at the highest a case of an error of judgment or breach of performance of duty which, per se, cannot be equated with dishonest intention to esta- blish the charge under section 42O I.P.C.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Relies on prior analysis for Accountant; High Court evidence insufficient for mens rea beyond reasonable doubt.

holdings.text: Administrative lapse, error of judgment, or breach of duty does not per se constitute mens rea or dishonest intention for cheating under section 420 IPC.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes civil/administrative failure from criminal intent; requires proof beyond reasonable doubt of guilty mind.

holdings.text: Appellants acquitted under section 420/34 IPC; High Court judgment set aside.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeals ,are allowed. The judgment of the High Court so far as these two appellants are companycerned is set aside. The two appellants herein are acquitted of the charge and shall be discharged from their bail bonds.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative failure to prove mens rea against both appellants.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeals ,are allowed. The judgment of the High Court so far as these two appellants are companycerned is set aside. The two appellants herein are acquitted of the charge and shall be discharged from their bail bonds.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals allowed; High Court judgment set aside for the two appellants; appellants acquitted
